sen.j: 雷神（らいじん）は、日本の民間信仰や神道における雷の神である。
sen.e: Raijin is the god of lightning in the Japanese folk beliefs and Shinto religion.
Raijin is the god of lightning in Japanese folk beliefs and the Shinto religion.
Raijin is the god of lightning in Japanese folk beliefs and the Shinto religion.

sen.j: 「雷様（かみなりさま）」「雷電様（らいでんさま）」「鳴神（なるかみ）」「雷公（らいこう）」とも呼ばれる。
sen.e: It is also called 'Kaminari-sama' (Mr. Thunder), 'Raiden-sama' (Mr. Thunderbolt), 'Narukami' (The Rolling God) or 'Rai-ko' (Duke Thunder).
It is also called 'Kaminari-sama' (Mr. Thunder), 'Raiden-sama' (Mr. Thunderbolt), 'Narukami' (The Rolling God) or 'Rai-ko' (Duke Thunder).
It is also called 'Kaminari-sama' (Mr. Thunder), 'Raiden-sama' (Mr. Thunderbolt), 'Narukami' (The Rolling God) or 'Rai-ko' (Duke Thunder).

sen.j: 菅原道真は死して天神（雷の神）になったと伝えられる。
sen.e: It is said that SUGAWARA no Michizane died and became Tenjin (god of lightening).
It is said that SUGAWARA no Michizane died and became Tenjin (god of lightening).
It is said that SUGAWARA no Michizane died and became Tenjin (god of lightening).

sen.j: 民間伝承では惧れと親しみをこめて雷神を「雷さま」と呼ぶことが多い。
sen.e: In folk beliefs, Raijin is often called as 'Kaminari-sama' endearingly.
In folk beliefs, Raijin is often called as 'Kaminari-sama' endearingly.
In folk beliefs, Raijin is often called as 'Kaminari-sama' fearfully and endearingly.
sen.cmt: 「惧れ」を fearfully として追記しました。

sen.j: 雷さまは落ちては人のヘソをとると言い伝えられている。
sen.e: It has been believed that Kaminari-sama falls from the sky and picks somebody's bellybutton.
sen.cmt: 「雷さまは（空から）落ちては」と補って訳しました。
sen.e: It has been believed that Kaminari-sama falls from the sky and picks somebody's bellybutton.
It has been believed that Kaminari-sama falls from the sky and picks somebody's bellybutton.

sen.j: 日本の子どもは夏に腹を出していると「かみなりさまがへそを取りにくるよ」と周りの大人から脅かされる。
sen.e: In Japan, adults scare children by saying, "Kaminari-sama would come to pick your bellybutton," when the children's bellies are uncovered in summer.
In Japan, adults scare children by saying, "Kaminari-sama would come to pick your bellybutton," when the children's bellies are uncovered in summer.
In Japan, adults scare children by saying, 'Kaminari-sama would come to pick your bellybutton,' when the children's bellies are uncovered in summer.

sen.j: 雷さまから逃れるための方法論としては、蚊帳に逃げ込む、桑原（くわばら：菅原道真の亡霊が雷さまとなり、都に被害をもたらしたが、道真の領地の桑原には雷が落ちなかったと言う伝承から由来）と唱える、などが伝えられる。
sen.e: There are some methodologies to escape from Kaminari-sama; the methods such as escaping into a mosquito net, repeating the word "kuwabara (this comes from a tradition that Kaminari-sama, who was the ghost of SUGAWARA no Michizane, caused serious damage in the capital, but Kuwabara, the territory of Michizane, was never hit by thunder)" have been believed as effective.

There are some methodologies to escape from Kaminari-sama; the methods such as escaping into a mosquito net, repeating the word "kuwabara (this comes from a tradition that Kaminari-sama, who was the ghost of SUGAWARA no Michizane, caused serious damage in the capital, but Kuwabara, the territory of Michizane, was never hit by thunder)" have been believed as effective.

There are some methodologies to escape from Kaminari-sama; the methods such as escaping into a mosquito net, repeating the word "kuwabara (this comes from a tradition that Kaminari-sama, who was the ghost of SUGAWARA no Michizane, caused serious damage in the capital, but Kuwabara, the territory of Michizane, was never hit by thunder)" have been believed as effective.

sen.j: 対になる存在としては風神が挙げられる。
sen.e: Fujin (wind god) is cited as another pair of Raijin.
Fujin (wind god) is cited as another pair of Raijin.
Fujin (wind god) is cited as another pair of Raijin.

sen.j: 日本では俵屋宗達の風神雷神図(屏風)を代表例に、雷さまは鬼の様態で、ウシの角を持ちトラの皮革のふんどしを締め、太鼓（雷鼓）を打ち鳴らす姿が馴染み深い。
sen.e: In Japan, as Sotatsu TAWARAYA's Fujin Raijin zu (The Wind and Thunder Gods: a folding screen), a representative example, shows, Kaminari-sama holding a cow's horn, wearing the tiger leather fundoshi, and beating a drum possessed by the god of thunder is the Raijin's well-known appearance.

In Japan, as Sotatsu TAWARAYA's Fujin Raijin zu (The Wind and Thunder Gods: a folding screen), a representative example, shows, Kaminari-sama holding a cow's horn, wearing the tiger leather fundoshi, and beating a drum being possessed by the god of thunder is the Raijin's well-known image.

In Japan, as Sotatsu TAWARAYA's Fujin Raijin zu (The Wind and Thunder Gods: a folding screen), a representative example, shows, Kaminari-sama holding a cow's horn, wearing the tiger leather fundoshi, and beating a drum being possessed by the god of thunder is the Raijin's well-known image.

sen.j: この姿は鬼門（方位東洋の方位＝丑寅：うしとら）の連想から由来する。
sen.e: This appearance derives from the image associated from Kimon (the northeastern (unlucky) direction, person or thing to be avoided), that is the oriental bearings, Ox and Tigar (northeast in Western ones).
This image derives from being associated with Kimon (the northeast, an unlucky direction, person or thing to be avoided), that is the oriental bearings, Ox and Tiger (northeast in the Western sense).
This image derives from being associated with Kimon (the northeast, an unlucky direction, person or thing to be avoided), that is the oriental bearings, Ox and Tiger (northeast in the Western sense).

sen.j: 雷が落ちる時「雷獣」という怪獣が落ちてくるともいう。
sen.e: It is also said that a monster called as 'Raiju' (Thunder Monster) when the lightning hits.
It is also said that there is a monster is called 'Raiju' (Thunder Monster) when lightning hits.
It is also said that a monster called 'Raiju' (Thunder Monster) is falling when lightning hits.
sen.cmt: that 以下を書き換えました。

sen.j: 大津絵のなかでは雷さまは雲の上から落としてしまった太鼓を鉤で釣り上げようとするなどユーモラスに描かれている。
sen.e: In Otsu-e (Otsu paintings, named after the town of Otsu in Shiga Prefecture), Kaminari-sama is depicted in a humorous way; for example, Kaminari-sama trying to hook the drum that he dropped from the cloud is depicted there.

In Otsu-e (Otsu paintings, named after the town of Otsu in Shiga Prefecture), Kaminari-sama is depicted in a humorous way; for example, Kaminari-sama trying to hook the drum that he dropped from the cloud is depicted there.

In Otsu-e (Otsu paintings, named after the town of Otsu in Shiga Prefecture), Kaminari-sama is depicted in a humorous way; for example, Kaminari-sama trying to hook the drum that he dropped from the cloud is depicted there.

tit.j: 上賀茂神社（賀茂別雷神社）

sen.j: - 賀茂別雷神（かもわけいかづちのかみ）
sen.e: - Kamowakeikazuchi no Kami
- Kamowakeikazuchi no Kami

sen.j: - 菅原道真（火雷天神、からいてんじん）の天神信仰による
sen.e: - from Tenjin-shinko (a faith in Tenjin) of SUGAWARA no Michizane (Karai Tenjin (the heavenly god of fire-causing thunder))
- from Tenjin-shinko (a faith in Tenjin) of SUGAWARA no Michizane (Karai Tenjin - the heavenly god of fire-causing thunder)
- from Tenjin-shinko (a faith in Tenjin) of SUGAWARA no Michizane (Karai Tenjin - the heavenly god of fire-causing thunder)

sen.j: - 建御雷神(たけみかづち)
sen.e: - Takemikazuchi-no-kami
- Takemikazuchi-no-kami

sen.j: - 火雷神（ほのいかづちのかみ）・大雷神（おおいかづちのかみ）・別雷神（わけいかづちのかみ） など
sen.e: - Honoikazuchi no Kami (the god of fire-causing thunder)・Oikazuchi no kami・Wakeikazuchi no kami, etc.
- Honoikazuchi no Kami (the god of fire-causing thunder)・Oikazuchi no kami・Wakeikazuchi no kami, etc.

sen.e: Yatsuikatsuchi no kami'

tit.j: 歴史・文学の中の雷神

sen.j: 古事記：建御雷神ほか
sen.e: Kojiki (The Records of Ancient Matters): Takemikazuchi-no-kami, etc.
Kojiki (The Records of Ancient Matters): Takemikazuchi-no-kami, etc.
Kojiki (The Records of Ancient Matters): Takemikazuchi-no-kami, etc.

sen.j: 季語一覧：雷神は 「雷」「はたたがみ」「雷鳴」などと同じく「晩夏」の季語である。
sen.e: List of season words: Raijin is a season word of the late summer, like 'lightning,' 'violent thunder' and 'thunderclap.'
List of season words: Raijin is a season word of the late summer, like 'lightning,' 'violent thunder,' and 'thunderclap.'
List of season words: Raijin is a season word of 'the late summer', like 'lightning,' 'violent thunder,' and 'thunderclap.'

sen.j: 能「雷電 (能)」は後シテが雷神である。
sen.e: In Noh 'Raiden', Nochi-Shite (the leading role in the latter half of a Noh play) is Raijin.
In Noh 'Raiden', Nochi-Shite (the leading role in the latter half of a Noh play) is Raijin.
In Noh 'Raiden', Nochi-Shite (the leading role in the latter half of a Noh play) is Raijin.

sen.j: 歌舞伎演目の「鳴神（なるかみ）」は「雷神不動北山桜（なるかみふどうきたやまざくら）」の一部
sen.e: Narukami (The Rolling God)' of Kabuki program is a part of 'Narukamifudo Kitayamazakura.'
Narukami (The Rolling God)' of Kabuki program is a part of 'Narukamifudo Kitayamazakura.'
Narukami (The Rolling God)' of Kabuki program is a part of 'Narukamifudo Kitayamazakura.'

sen.j: ギリシア神話のゼウス、ローマ神話のジュピター、北欧神話のトールなど、世界各地の神話に「雷の神」が現れる。
sen.e: God of lightning' appears in the world's mythologies such as Zeus of Greek mythology, Jupiter of Roman mythology, Thor of Norse mythology.
God of lightning' appears in the world's mythologies such as Zeus of Greek mythology, Jupiter of Roman mythology, Thor of Norse mythology.
God of lightning' appears in the world's mythologies such as Zeus of Greek mythology, Jupiter of Roman mythology, Thor of Norse mythology.

sen.j: 中国では雷公(enLei Gong)，雷師，雷祖などと呼ばれている。
sen.e: In China, it is called as Rai-ko (enLei Gong), Rai-shi, Rai-so, and so on.
In China, it is called Rai-ko (enLei Gong), Rai-shi, Rai-so, and so on.
